DataElement.preferredName: Separate Submission Specimen Ductal Carcinoma in Situ Margin Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text indicator to signify the presence of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) in the margin(s) of separately submitted specimen margins.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Separate Submission Specimen Ductal Carcinoma in Situ Margin
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Reference to the presence of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) in the margin(s) of separately submitted specimen margins.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Not accompanied by another or others.:Submission; a message submitted for the judgment of others.:Specimen; a bit of tissue or blood or urine that is taken or used for research purposes.

Concepts.definition: Not accompanied by another or others; exclusive of anyone or anything else.
Something submitted for the judgment or consideration of others.

A part of a thing, or of several things, taken to demonstrate or to determine the character of the whole, e.g. a substance, or portion of material obtained for use in testing, examination, or study; particularly, a preparation of tissue or bodily fluid taken for examination or diagnosis.

Property.preferredName: Ductal Breast Carcinoma In Situ Margin
Property.preferredDefinition: Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is a carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts. There is no evidence of invasion of the basement membrane. Currently, DCIS is classified into three categories: High-grade DCIS, intermediate-grade DCIS and low-grade DCIS. In this classification the DCIS grade is defined by a combination of nuclear grade, architectural growth pattern and presence of necrosis. The size of the lesion as well as the grade and the clearance margins play a major role in dictating the most appropriate therapy for DCIS. --2002:Margin; the boundary line or the area immediately inside the boundary.

Concepts.definition: A breast carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts. It is also known as DCIS. There is no evidence of invasion of the basement membrane. Currently, it is classified into three categories: High-grade DCIS, intermediate-grade DCIS and low-grade DCIS. In this classification the DCIS grade is defined by a combination of nuclear grade, architectural growth pattern and presence of necrosis. The size of the lesion as well as the grade and the clearance margins play a major role in dictating the most appropriate therapy for DCIS.
A boundary line or the area immediately inside the boundary.
